[Header]

WORK AND WEALTH INSEPARABLE ALLIES
THE THREE GREAT FACTORS OF MODERN CIVILIZATION—THE PRINTING PRESS, THE PUBLIC SCHOOL AND THE RAILROAD

There be three things which make a nation great and prosperous—a fertile soil, busy workshops and easy convey- ance for man and goods from place to place. —BACON. The Railroad in Education
ALEX. HOGG
(LATE SUPERINTENDENT CITY PUBLIC SCHOOLS) Of all inventions, the alphabet and printing press alone excepted, those in- ventions which abridge distance have done the most for civilization. —MACAULAY.
[Dateline]

FORT WORTH, TEXAS, March 7" 1908

[Body]

My dear McInnis:
You will see from
the smallest slip, that Henderson
does nothing but "damn" the H. Schools
and tell them how they must teach
in order to be affiliated with the
University. It seems to me that
in your reorganization you should
take some steps to head off such
work by putting in the field men
there are that should look after
the interests of the 90 per cent that
never reach the High School much
less the University. I hope to meet
you before your Summer Commencement
over

**I've received this handwritten letter and I'm diving in to transcribe it accurately.** First, I'm doing a visual inspection to grasp its overall structure. I see a header with a motto about work and wealth, along with two quotes from Bacon and Macaulay, and then a title about the railroad's role in education. There's a dateline, "Fort Worth, Texas, March 7" 1908", and a salutation to "McInnis" (or is it McGinnis?).

The main part of the task is the body of the letter. The first line is straightforward, but quickly, I encounter an unclear word. "Henderson" is the subject, and the writer says he "does nothing but [word] the H. Schools." This [word] is the real challenge. The writer then explains what Henderson is doing; i.e., telling these schools how to teach if they want affiliation with the University. It's a complaint, and I'm parsing this [word] for meaning. The word looks like "damn" or "drum" or "drive". Contextually, "damn" seems plausible, given that this writer is complaining about Henderson. But is it "drum" as in "drumming" information into them? Or "drive"? The handwritten word has two dots over it. It looks like "d-a-m-n" (damn), with the dots as emphasis, but the context is all about education. The dots are the issue. Maybe they're noise, but I can't ignore them. "Drive" seems to fit "driving" the schools to conform, but the visual evidence of the shape is not perfect for that either. "Drive" has an 'i', the dots suggest "i". The writer seems to be trying to control these schools. It’s a very colloquial word. Ultimately, I'm going with "damn" as it’s the most consistent in terms of the style, but with an acknowledgement that "drive" might be intended.

The next lines discuss a reorganization, and the writer's suggesting to take "some steps to head off such work by putting in the field men." This is another tricky spot. What kind of "field men"? "Men" is at the end of the line. The word before "men" looks like "field". But what comes after? Is it "men / who are / men" or something like that? The phrase is "putting in the field men [who] [what]". The word looks like "there". Putting "field" men "there are that should". "There are" feels archaic, but fits. Or is it "than one", which makes more sense, and is a possibility? The shape of the word looks like "there". This is the best interpretation: "putting in the field men / there are that should". I'm going to transcribe it as "men there are".

The remainder is straightforward: it references the 90 percent of students who don't reach the High School and the University and hopes to see "McGinnis" before summer commencement. I've re-checked the handwritten form of the word "damn" and am making a final decision: it is most likely "damn". The name "McInnis" seems right too, if the 'I' is not a 'G'. Now, I just need to format the transcript and I'm done.

I am sending you a communication
in regard to School Houses their
height &c
When at the door night after night
I thought of that tall building, and
under the roof over 100 human souls
Me strictly "inter nos" - History often
repeats itself - and even revolutions
do sometimes go backwards Can you
afford to go back again?
I do not know what it is, but there is something
behind.
Well Well! I know nothing hence I
have nothing to say - as ever
Your friend
Alex Hogg

I am sending you my
last utterance for the
Better Remuneration for Teachers
In the slip of Professor Smith you
mean while I am trying to do
so
